inlineContent.text: Configuration objects define how ARKit sets up and runs your augmented reality session. Although

provides the widest range of features in a rear-camera experience, each feature consumes device energy and compute cycles. So to maximize device uptime and performance, enable additional options sparingly.
If another AR configuration fulfills your requirements with a more concise feature set, use that configuration instead. For example, use
instead of a world-tracking configuration for 3D motion-capture if you don’t need user face-tracking, collaboration, or scene reconstruction.
Some configurations support subfeatures that relate to a session’s frame. Enable these features by setting the following flags in the configuration’s
Enables 2D human body tracking.
Enables people occlusion.
Enables people occlusion based on whether the people in the camera feed are closer to the camera than the virtual content.
Use
to verify whether the iOS device supports the
you desire before setting
To maximize device responsiveness, refrain from turning on people occlusion for single-user experiences when you don’t expect people in the scene.
To toggle features like plane detection, frame semantics, and environment texturing, you switch your configuration at runtime by calling

on your existing session. Where possible, ARKit maintains all the information collected during the session under the prior configuration, such as information about the physical environment and anchors.

You can gracefully downgrade the AR experience in the event of low-power or thermal events. For example, you could temporarily switch from a world-tracking configuration to a position-tracking configuration (
) if your app can function at a basic level in that limited capacity until the device cools down.
If your session switches between face- and world-tracking configurations, the session doesn’t maintain state.

content.text: Enable high-quality video and custom capture settings

inlineContent.text: In iOS 16, you can enable a 4K and high dynamic range (HDR) video format. In addition, you can customize your session’s video settings through the underlying AV capture device.
To determine whether your session supports 4K, call

code: print("4K video format not supported."); return }

inlineContent.text: Then, create a configuration with the format. You can also indicate the intent to enable HDR by setting
to
If the device supports a configurable capture session, the
provides the underlying capture device that you can adjust as needed.
In iOS 16, you can enable high-resolution frame capture by calling
on your configuration. If the device supports high-resolution stills, the function returns a video format you can use to start a session:

code: fatalError("The device doesn't support high-resolution stills.") }

inlineContent.text: During the session, capture a high-resolution still frame at any time by calling

abstract.text: Configure your augmented reality session to detect and track specific types of content.
A configuration that tracks the position of a device in relation to objects in the environment.
Enables high dynamic range (HDR) for the session’s camera feed.
Returns a video format that the framework recommends for high-resolution-still-image capture.
Types of optional frame features you can enable in your app.
The set of active semantics on the frame.
The object that manages the major tasks associated with every AR experience, such as motion tracking, camera passthrough, and image analysis.
Provides a 4K video format if the device and configuration support it.
A configuration that tracks facial movement and expressions using the front camera.
A configuration that tracks only the device’s position in 3D space.
An object that enables you to alter the appearance of a frame’s captured image.
Discover features and best practices for building rear-camera AR experiences.
A configuration that tracks known images using the rear-facing camera.
A configuration that recognizes objects and collects high-fidelity data about specific objects using the rear-facing camera.
An option that indicates that people occlude your app’s virtual content depending on depth.
An option that indicates that 2D body detection is enabled.

doc://com.apple.arkit/documentation/ARKi.title: Displaying an AR Experience with Metal

abstract.text: Control rendering of your app’s virtual content on top of a camera feed.
Requests a frame outside of the normal frequency that contains a high-resolution captured image.
A configuration that tracks only the device’s orientation using the rear-facing camera.
Keep the user informed on the current session state and recover from interruptions.

doc://com.apple.arkit/documentation/ARKi.title: Managing Session Life Cycle and Tracking Quality

abstract.text: Integrate iOS device camera and motion features to produce augmented reality experiences in your app or game.
A configuration that tracks human body poses, planar surfaces, and images using the rear-facing camera.
Integrate hardware sensing features to produce augmented reality apps and games.
An option that indicates that people occlude your app’s virtual content.

doc://com.apple.arkit/documentation/ARKi.title: Choosing Which Camera Feed to Augment

abstract.text: Add visual effects to the user’s environment in an AR experience through the front or rear camera.
The base object that contains information about how to configure an augmented reality session.
Starts AR processing for the session with the specified configuration.
A configuration that tracks locations with GPS, map data, and a device’s compass.
Checks whether a particular feature is supported.
